publications.Title: Developing a method for creating structured representations of working of systems from natural language descriptions using the SAPPhIRE model of causality
publications.Author: K Bhattacharya, A Majumder, AN Bhatt, S Keshwani, BSC Ranjan, A Chakrabarti
publications.Abstract: This paper presents a method for creating structured representations of the working of systems from natural language descriptions using the SAPPhIRE model of causality. The method leverages natural language processing techniques to automatically extract and structure causal relationships from textual descriptions, enabling systematic analysis and comparison of system behaviors.
publications.APA: Bhattacharya, K., Majumder, A., Bhatt, A. N., Keshwani, S., Ranjan, B. S. C., & Chakrabarti, A. (2024). Developing a method for creating structured representations of working of systems from natural language descriptions using the SAPPhIRE model of causality. Artificial Intelligence for Engineering Design, Analysis and Manufacturing, 38, e24. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0890060424000118

publications.Title: Comparing Analogy-Based Methods—Bio-Inspiration and Engineering-Domain Inspiration for Domain Selection and Novelty
publications.Author: S Keshwani, H Casakin
publications.Abstract: This study explores how different analogy domains—biological, cross-domain engineering, and within-domain engineering—influence design novelty and selection frequency among novice product designers. Results indicate that biological analogies were frequently selected and significantly increased the novelty of designs compared to within-domain analogies. The research suggests that middle-domain analogies can be as effective as far-domain ones in promoting novelty.
publications.APA: Keshwani, S., & Casakin, H. (2024). Comparing analogy-based methods—Bio-inspiration and engineering-domain inspiration for domain selection and novelty. Biomimetics, 9(6), 344. https://doi.org/10.3390/biomimetics9060344

publications.Title: Influence of analogical domains and comprehensiveness in explanation of analogy on the novelty of designs
publications.Author: S Keshwani, A Chakrabarti
publications.Abstract: This paper investigates the influence of analogical domains and the comprehensiveness of analogy explanations on the novelty of design outcomes. The study examines how designers utilize analogies from different domains and how the level of detail in analogy presentation affects the creative design process and resulting design novelty.
publications.APA: Keshwani, S., & Chakrabarti, A. (2017). Influence of analogical domains and comprehensiveness in explanation of analogy on the novelty of designs. Research in Engineering Design, 28(3), 381–410. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00163-016-0246-z

publications.Title: Comparing novelty of designs from biological-inspiration with those from brainstorming
publications.Author: S Keshwani, TA Lenau, S Ahmed-Kristensen, A Chakrabarti
publications.Abstract: This research aims to understand the significance of biological analogies in fostering novelty by comparing them with brainstorming for idea generation. Results indicate that concepts generated using 'biocards' (biological inspiration) were ideated at higher abstraction levels than those from brainstorming, and the average novelty of biocard-generated concepts was greater. The authors suggest that better training in using biological analogies can enhance design innovation.
publications.APA: Keshwani, S., Lenau, T. A., Ahmed-Kristensen, S., & Chakrabarti, A. (2017). Comparing novelty of designs from biological-inspiration with those from brainstorming. Journal of Engineering Design, 28(10-12), 654–680. https://doi.org/10.1080/09544828.2017.1393504
